Title: An integrable and periodic function $f(x)$ satisfies $\int_{0}^{T}f(x)dx=\int_{a}^{a+T}f(x)dx$.
Content: I want to prove: For an integrable function $f(x)$ and periodic with period $T$, for every $a \in \mathbb{R}$, $$\int_{0}^{T}f(x)\;dx=\int_{a}^{a+T}f(x)\;dx.$$ I tried to change the values and define $y=a+x$ so that $dy=dx$ and the limits of the integrals are as we want, but I'm not sure how to use the fact that $f(x)$ is periodic. Thanks a lot!
AcceptedAnswer:
If $F$ is a primitive of $f$, then $$\int_{a}^{a+T}f(x)\ dx-\int_{0}^{T}f(x)\ dx$$
$$=F(a+T)-F(a)-F(T)+F(0)$$
$$=\Big(F(a+T)-F(T)\Big)-\Big(F(a)-F(0)\Big)$$
$$=\int_T^{a+T}f(x)\ dx-\int_0^af(x)\ dx$$
$$=0.$$ One checks the last equality by making the obvious change of variable, and by using the periodicity. EDIT 1. What I wrote above is how I remember the computation. Of course, it can be written like that:
$$
\int_{a}^{a+T}f(x)\ dx-\int_{0}^{T}f(x)\ dx=\int_T^{a+T}f(x)\ dx-\int_0^af(x)\ dx=0.
$$ EDIT 2. Formal justification of the first equality in the above display:
$$
\int_0^af(x)\ dx+\int_{a}^{a+T}f(x)\ dx=\int_{0}^{T}f(x)\ dx+\int_T^{a+T}f(x)\ dx.
$$ (This formula should appear somewhere...)

Another idea: Since the function is periodic with period T, shifting the interval by any multiple of T doesn't change the integral. So perhaps we can express a as some integer multiple of T plus a remainder. For example, write a = k*T + b where k is an integer and 0 ≤ b < T. Then, the integral from a to a + T becomes from k*T + b to (k+1)*T + b. But because the function is periodic with period T, the integral from k*T to (k+1)*T is the same as from 0 to T. Then, the integral from k*T + b to (k+1)*T + b can be split into two parts: from k*T + b to (k+1)*T and then from (k+1)*T to (k+1)*T + b. Then, by periodicity, the first part is ∫_{b}^{T} f(x)dx and the second part is ∫_{T}^{T + b} f(x)dx = ∫_{0}^{b} f(x)dx because f(x + T) = f(x). So adding those two parts gives ∫_{0}^{T} f(x)dx. This uses the periodicity to shift the interval [T, a+T] back to [0, a]. Therefore, the integral over any interval of length T is the same as over [0, T].

Alternatively, consider that for any a, the integral ∫ₐ^{a+T} f(x)dx is equal to ∫₀^T f(x)dx.
